definitions.definition: an action or event that is a signal for somebody to do something

examples.text: Jon's arrival was a cue for more champagne.
I think that's my cue to explain why I'm here.
Her husband took his cue, and said that it was time for them to leave.
This remark provided the cue for the crowd to start jeering.
This was the cue for her to come into the room.

definitions.definition: a few words or an action in a play that is a signal for another actor to do something

examples.text: She stood in the wings and waited for her cue to go on.
He had not yet been given the cue to go on to the stage.

definitions.definition: a long wooden stick with a leather tip, used for hitting the ball in the games of billiards, pool and snooker
at exactly the moment you expect or that is appropriate

examples.text: ‘Where is that boy?’ As if on cue, Simon appeared in the doorway.
I can't just cry on cue!

definitions.definition: to copy what somebody else does as an example of how to behave or what to do

examples.text: Investors are taking their cue from the big banks and selling dollars.
They all took their cue from their leader.

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 2 mid 16th cent.: of unknown origin. noun sense 3 mid 18th cent. (denoting a long plait or pigtail): variant of queue.
